title: How to Make a Rooting Tonic

steps.headline: Collect approximately 2 cups of willow branches or 3 cups of bark.
steps.description: Choose small, young branches that are no thicker than a pencil. The highest concentration of hormone exists in the youngest branches. You can also use bark from live older willow branches or trunks. If you go this route, you need to use more bark because it contains less hormones. Do not gather old dead branches from the ground, as they will contain very little indolebutyric acid, if any.

steps.headline: Cut the willow branches into pieces between 3-to-6-inches long.
steps.description: If using bark, cut it into 2-to-4-inch pieces.

steps.headline: Put the willow into a pan or bowl that is large enough to hold the clippings plus a gallon of water.
Boil 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water and pour it over the willow clippings.
Allow the willow and hot water to brew for 12 to 24 hours.
Pour the liquid into glass containers with lids that close securely and discard the pieces of willow.
steps.description: You can store the tonic in the refrigerator for up to two months.

steps.headline: Use the rooting tonic when propagating new plants.
steps.description: Soak the tips of your cuttings in the rooting tonic for several hours before planting them. In addition to encouraging the growth of a strong root system, the willow rooting tonic inhibits the development of bacteria, fungus and viral disease.

text: Collect approximately 2 cups of willow branches or 3 cups of bark. Choose small, young branches that are no thicker than a pencil. The highest concentration of hormone exists in the youngest branches. You can also use bark from live older willow branches or trunks. If you go this route, you need to use more bark because it contains less hormones. Do not gather old dead branches from the ground, as they will contain very little indolebutyric acid, if any. Cut the willow branches into pieces between 3-to-6-inches long. If using bark, cut it into 2-to-4-inch pieces. Put the willow into a pan or bowl that is large enough to hold the clippings plus a gallon of water.  Boil 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water and pour it over the willow clippings.  Allow the willow and hot water to brew for 12 to 24 hours.  Pour the liquid into glass containers with lids that close securely and discard the pieces of willow. You can store the tonic in the refrigerator for up to two months. Use the rooting tonic when propagating new plants. Soak the tips of your cuttings in the rooting tonic for several hours before planting them. In addition to encouraging the growth of a strong root system, the willow rooting tonic inhibits the development of bacteria, fungus and viral disease.
